questions.question_text: A functional manager is concerned that the project's quality management techniques have advanced beyond the department's capabilities and wants the project team to review all quality management activities in two full-day workshops the following week. What should the project manager do next?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Explain that the team is fully dedicated to the current sprint activities and negotiate a mutually agreeable time

choices.A: Indicate that this was a not a requirement identified during project planning and it is outside of the scope.
choices.C: Explain that the team is fully dedicated to the current sprint activities and negotiate a mutually agreeable time.
choices.D: Add this to the project backlog and have the product owner determine where it fits in terms of priority.
choices.B: Draft a project decision request to include in the scope for the current iteration and ask the sponsor to approve.

questions.question_text:
A project manager is assigned to a dental equipment development project that is in the middle of its design phase. After reviewing the project prototype, it is identified that a couple of requirements specifications are missing.

Which action should the project manager take next?

choices.B: Discuss with the team and build a workaround plan to immediately deliver the pending requirements specifications.
choices.A: Ask the team to wait until they are able to update the requirements specifications.
choices.C: Meet with the development team to review and assess the requirements specifications.
choices.D: Prepare a change request for the change control board (CCB) to remove the missing requirements specifications.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Meet with the development team to review and assess the requirements specifications

questions.question_text:
A project manager uses a laissez-faire leadership style with a newly hired project team. The project manager quickly notices that team members are underperforming, the schedule is delayed, and the project is overbudget.

What should the project manager have done at the start of the project?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When working with a newly hired team, it's important for the project manager to provide clear guidance, direction, and support to help the team understand their roles and responsibilities. A direct management style ensures that the team has the necessary structure and oversight to perform effectively, especially in the early stages of the project. As the team becomes more experienced and confident, the project manager can gradually shift to a more hands-off approach if appropriate.
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
The project manager should have adapted a direct management style initially to provide the necessary structure, guidance, and support that a newly hired team needs to perform effectively. This would have mitigated delays and budget overruns by fostering clear expectations and active oversight from the start.

Selected Answer: B
B. Adapted a direct management style according to the project team's needs

Selected Answer: B
In this scenario direct management style is the best. (B)

Selected Answer: C
C. Established goals and provided the project team with sufficient authority to work

questions.question_text:
In a geographically distributed project team, the project team members continue to email status reports and update schedules after their weekly meeting discussions. However, the team is having difficulty tracking the changes and progress made.
What should the project manager do?

discussion.content:
I go with "C". 1st Hint is "Team geographically distributed" & " every weekly meeting after using mail to send status report & schedule updates. Here real impediment is tracking the reports from various locations.
Training is required if team members not understand or having issues to follow the existing communication. But its not reflected in asked question.
So, Maintain a central repository of artifacts with a version control system is good option to collect reports, tracking changes and progress can made.

I think A.
The question does not mention that the artifacts are not in a center repository. The problem is that member does not know how to using the version control so training is necessary.

comments.content: the team is having difficulty tracking the changes

Change my answer to C.
The question imply that artifacts are not in a center repository.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I think C is the answer, I believe they need a central repository system like SharePoint with version control enabled where each team member can share and access project documentation to effectively track the status of the project

Selected Answer: A
Option A seems more appropriate.
First, why isn't the team using a version control system? There are 2 possible answers to this:
1. Either there is a version control system already in place but the team doesn't know how to use it.
2. There is no version control system available.

Either way, the team will need to learn how to use the version control system before we start talking about maintaining it. Also, is it the project manager who maintains the version control system or the project team?

A. Facilitate training on version control and project artifacts.

This option is out. Good option but after training, a version control system will be required else there is no point of giving the training. 

B. Maintain separate document control via regions to avoid discrepancies.

Why document control via region? Question never says documents from different region should be separated.

C. Maintain a central repository of artifacts with a version control system.

Correct option. Setting up central repository will eliminate confusions and will help to track changes

D. Develop a document management software for version control.

Option D is out? Should we really keep the project work aside and start working on developing a version control software?

Selected Answer: C
C. Maintain a central repository of artifacts with a version control system.
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Version control is a powerful tool that allows teams to track and manage changes to a set of files over time. Initially used in the software industry, version control has proven to be a fundamental tool for agile development, as it promotes collaboration, history tracking, rollback, and code review.
Answer is A

Selected Answer: C
C. Maintain a central repository of artifacts with a version control system
I voted D as it did not hint at having a central spot in place, therefore, I thought developing one would make more sense.
